questions.text: A woman presents with dysuria and yellowish discharge. Gram staining shows gram-negative diplococci. What is the diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Neisseria

 

The presence of gram-negative diplococci on a gram stain is a classic finding in infections caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae, which is a sexually transmitted bacterium responsible for gonorrhea. Neisseria gonorrhoeae typically presents with symptoms such as dysuria (painful urination) and a yellowish or purulent discharge, which aligns with the clinical presentation described in the question.

 

Gram staining is a key diagnostic tool that helps differentiate bacterial species based on the characteristics of their cell walls. Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a gram-negative diplococcus, meaning it appears as paired spherical bacteria that do not retain the crystal violet stain used in gram staining but do take up the counterstain, appearing pink or red under a microscope.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Trichomoniasis: This is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the protozoan Trichomonas vaginalis, which is a flagellated organism. While trichomoniasis can cause dysuria and yellowish discharge, it would not present with gram-negative diplococci on a gram stain. If the organism had flagella, Trichomoniasis would be a consideration, but the gram stain findings rule it out.

 

Option C. Chlamydia: Chlamydia trachomatis is another sexually transmitted bacterium that can cause symptoms similar to those of gonorrhea. However, it does not appear as gram-negative diplococci on gram stain. Instead, it is typically detected by nucleic acid amplification tests (NAAT).

 

Option D. Bacterial vaginosis: This condition is characterized by an imbalance in the vaginal flora and typically diagnosed using Amsel's criteria or by identifying clue cells on microscopy. It is not associated with gram-negative diplococci.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The identification of gram-negative diplococci in a patient with dysuria and yellowish discharge is highly indicative of Neisseria gonorrhoeae infection, a common cause of gonorrhea

choices.text: Abdominal sling surgery

questions.text: A 24-year-old nulligravida presents with uterine prolapse. There is no cystocele or rectocele. What is the treatment of choice? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Abdominal sling surgery

 

The correct answer is abdominal sling surgery. In a young nulligravida (a woman who has never been pregnant), the preferred treatment for uterine prolapse without cystocele or rectocele is usually a type of sling surgery, also known as hysteropexy. This procedure involves suspending the uterus to a supportive structure within the pelvis, preserving the uterus and maintaining the possibility of future pregnancies.

 

Abdominal sling surgery (Hysteropexy): This procedure is indicated for young women, particularly those who have not completed their family or desire future fertility. It involves attaching the uterus to a ligament or other supportive structure in the pelvis to provide the necessary support and correct the prolapse.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Leforte colpocleisis: This is a procedure typically reserved for very old women who are no longer sexually active and not fit for major surgery. It involves closing off the vaginal canal, which is not suitable for a young nulligravida.

 

Option B. Fothergill surgery (Manchester operation): This procedure involves cervical amputation and plication of the cardinal ligaments. It is more suitable for women who have completed their families because it can affect future fertility and pregnancy outcomes.

 

Option C. Shirodkar surgery: Although similar to sling surgeries, Shirodkar is more commonly associated with cervical cerclage to prevent preterm birth rather than correcting uterine prolapse.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a young nulligravida with uterine prolapse and no cystocele or rectocele, abdominal sling surgery (hysteropexy) is the treatment of choice to preserve fertility and provide effective prolapse correction.

questions.text: A teenage patient presented with a history of dysmenorrhea and chronic pelvic pain. On ultrasonography, a transverse vaginal septum was seen. Which of the following is she likely to have? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Endometriosis

 

Endometriosis:

 

  • A transverse vaginal septum is a type of Mullerian anomaly, which can be low, mid, or high and can be complete or incomplete.
  • It can present as primary amenorrhea with cyclical abdominal pain if complete.
  • The obstruction to blood flow caused by a transverse vaginal septum can lead to the accumulation of blood in the vagina (hematocolpos) and uterus (hematometra), which can subsequently cause retrograde menstruation and result in endometriosis.
  • The chronic pelvic pain and dysmenorrhea in this patient are consistent with endometriosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tubo-ovarian abscess: Tubo-ovarian abscess is typically associated with pelvic inflammatory disease and presents with fever, lower abdominal pain, and a tender adnexal mass. It is not directly related to Mullerian anomalies like a transverse vaginal septum.

 

Option C. Dermoid cyst: Dermoid cysts (mature cystic teratomas) are benign ovarian tumors that typically do not cause dysmenorrhea or chronic pelvic pain related to menstrual obstruction. They are not associated with Mullerian anomalies.

 

Option D. Theca lutein cyst: Theca lutein cysts are often associated with high levels of human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) and are seen in conditions like molar pregnancy and multiple gestations. They do not cause symptoms related to menstrual obstruction and are not associated with Mullerian anomalies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transverse vaginal septum, a Mullerian anomaly, can cause obstruction to menstrual flow leading to hematocolpos, hematometra, and endometriosis, presenting with dysmenorrhea and chronic pelvic pain.

 

Ref: Page no 34, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 8th edition

questions.text: A 28-year-old married woman who is anxious to conceive presents with copious vaginal discharge, without any itching. Her last menstrual period was 13 days ago. What is the cause of her vaginal discharge? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Physiological

 

Physiological:

 

  • The discharge described is white with no pruritus and occurs mid-cycle (ovulatory) with a short duration, which is most likely physiological.
  • Increased physiological discharge is common during:
    • Puberty
    • Ovulation
    • Pregnancy
    • Occasionally during the premenstrual phase
  • It may be cervical or vaginal in origin. A speculum examination of the vagina can distinguish between the two. If the discharge is cervical in origin, an excessive mucoid discharge will be visible at the external os.
  • Normal discharge appears clear or white, without any odor or itching, and has a pH of 3.8-4.2.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Candidiasis:

 

  • Typically presents with white, curdy discharge associated with intense itching and vulvar irritation.
  • The discharge often has a cottage cheese-like appearance.

 

Option B. Bacterial vaginosis:

 

  • Characterized by a thin, grayish-white, homogenous discharge with a fishy odor, especially noticeable after intercourse.
  • Itching is less common.

 

Option C. Trichomoniasis:

 

  • Presents with frothy, yellow-green discharge with a strong odor.
  • Associated with vaginal itching, burning, and discomfort during intercourse.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Physiological vaginal discharge is typically clear or white, without odor or itching, and can occur at ovulation, puberty, pregnancy, or occasionally during the premenstrual phase.

 

 

Ref: Page no 554, DC Dutta’s Textbook of gynecology 6th edition

choices.text: 3 swab test

questions.text: What is the most useful test in vesicovaginal fistula? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cystoscopy

 

Explanation:

 

Cystoscopy is the most useful test for diagnosing vesicovaginal fistula (VVF). It allows direct visualization of the bladder and can help identify the exact location, size, and number of fistulas. Additionally, cystoscopy can be used to assess the bladder for any associated injuries or other abnormalities.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. 3 swab test: This test is used to identify the type of genitourinary fistula (vesicovaginal or ureterovaginal) but is not as specific as cystoscopy for visualizing the fistula directly.

 

Option C. MRI: While MRI can provide detailed images of the pelvic structures and help in the diagnosis of fistulas, it is not the first-line investigation. It is more useful in complex cases or when additional information is needed.

 

Option D. Cystometry: This test evaluates bladder filling and voiding problems and is not specific for diagnosing vesicovaginal fistula.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cystoscopy is the most useful test for directly visualizing vesicovaginal fistulas, determining their size, location, and number, and assessing the bladder for any associated injuries.

 

Ref: Page no 417, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: A chorionic villous sampling is done at 12 weeks in a woman whose blood group is B negative. Her husband's blood group is A positive. What is the dose of Anti D given? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 50

 

Explanation:

 

In the case of Rh incompatibility, where the mother is Rh-negative (B negative) and the father is Rh-positive (A positive), there is a risk of fetal-maternal hemorrhage (FMH) during invasive procedures like chorionic villous sampling (CVS). This can lead to the mixing of fetal and maternal blood, potentially causing the mother to form antibodies against the Rh-positive fetal red blood cells. To prevent this alloimmunization, an Anti-D immunoglobulin injection is administered.

 

The standard practice is to give Anti-D immunoglobulin during any inciting event (e.g., CVS, amniocentesis, abdominal trauma, abruption, placenta previa) and at delivery. Additionally, it is given prophylactically at 28 weeks of gestation to all Rh-negative women.

 

The dosage of Anti-D depends on the gestational age:

 

 

Less than 12 weeks: 50 micrograms intramuscularly.

 

More than 12 weeks: 300 micrograms intramuscularly.

 

Since the CVS was performed at 12 weeks, the appropriate dose of Anti-D is 50 micrograms.

 

Educational objective:

 

For Rh-negative women undergoing an inciting event like chorionic villous sampling at less than 12 weeks gestation, the dose of Anti-D given is 50 micrograms.

choices.text: Pain begins after few hours of onset of periods and can last up to 48 hours
It is dependent on psychological factors
Pain begins 3 days prior to the onset of periods and is present up to the second day of the period
GnRH antagonists are the first line of treatment

questions.text: Which of these statements regarding primary dysmenorrhea is true? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It Is dependent on psychological factors

 

Primary dysmenorrhea can be dependent on psychological factors.

 

Secondary dysmenorrhea is associated with the presence of pelvic pathologies.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Pain begins after few hours of onset of periods and can last up to 48 hours and Option C. Pain begins 3 days prior to the onset of periods and is present up to the second day of the period: Pain begins before or with onset of menstrual periods.

 

Option D. GnRH antagonists are the first line of treatment: NSAIDs are the first line of treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primary dysmenorrhea, characterized by menstrual pain without underlying pelvic pathology, can be influenced by psychological factors. This type of dysmenorrhea begins before or with the onset of menstrual periods and is typically treated first with NSAIDs, not GnRH antagonists.

questions.text: Fimbriectomy is also known as? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Kroner’s procedure

 

Explanation:

 

Fimbriectomy is a method of tubal ligation where the fimbriated end of the Fallopian tube is ligated and excised. This technique is also known as Kroner’s procedure.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Pomeroy technique: In this method, the mid-isthmic portion of the Fallopian tube is elevated and then folded at the midpoint. One or two rapidly absorbable sutures are tied around the double thickness of the tube, and the folded portion is excised sharply.

 

Option B. Uchida's procedure: This involves ligating and excising the midportion of the Fallopian tube. The utero-tubal serosa is then hydro-dissected, and the proximal tubal stump is pulled into the mesosalpinx. The peritoneum is closed over the proximal cut end of the tube.

 

Option D. Irving's procedure: In this method, the midportion of the Fallopian tube is ligated and excised. The proximal tubal stump is inserted into an incision made into the myometrium and securely sutured to bury the proximal stump in the myometrium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fimbriectomy, also known as Kroner's procedure, involves ligation and excision of the fimbriated end of the Fallopian tube.

 

Ref: Page no 497, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

choices.text: Colposcopy with LEEP

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman has cervical intraepithelial neoplasia III. What would be the management? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Colposcopy with LEEP

 

Explanation:

 

Cervical intraepithelial neoplasia III (CIN 3) is a severe form of cervical dysplasia that is diagnosed by cervical biopsy. The standard treatment for CIN 2 or CIN 3 is an excisional procedure, which aims to remove the affected tissue to prevent progression to invasive cancer.

 

  • LEEP (Loop Electrosurgical Excision Procedure):
    • LEEP is the excisional procedure of choice for treating CIN 3.
    • It involves using a thin wire loop that is heated by electric current to excise the transformation zone of the cervix where abnormal cells are located.
    • LEEP is also known as LLETZ (Large Loop Excision of the Transformation Zone).

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Hysterectomy: This is a more radical procedure that involves the removal of the uterus. It is generally not the first-line treatment for CIN 3 unless there are other indications, such as concurrent invasive cancer or other gynecological conditions.

 

Option B. Trachelectomy: This procedure involves removing the cervix while preserving the uterus. It is more commonly used for early-stage cervical cancer in women who wish to preserve fertility.

 

Option C. Conization: While conization (removal of a cone-shaped piece of tissue from the cervix) is a valid treatment for CIN 3, LEEP is often preferred due to its effectiveness and lower morbidity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CIN 3 is best treated with an excisional procedure, with the Loop Electrosurgical Excision Procedure (LEEP) being the procedure of choice.

 

Ref: Page no 328, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: Match the following syndromes with their respective karyotypes?  (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-A, 2-B, 3-D, 4-C

 

Explanation:

 

  • MRKH syndrome (Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser): This syndrome has a karyotype of 46XX.
  • Swyer Syndrome: This condition is characterized by 46XY karyotype.
  • Turner Syndrome: This is due to monosomy X, having a karyotype of 45XO.
  • Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome: This condition occurs in individuals with a karyotype of 46XY, where there is a complete androgen insensitivity, resulting in a phenotypically female appearance despite having male (XY) chromosomes.

 

Matching:

 

  1. MRKH: 46XX
  2. Swyer Syndrome: 46XY
  3. Turner Syndrome: 45XO
  4. Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome: 46XY

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding the karyotypes associated with different syndromes helps in diagnosing and managing these conditions effectively. MRKH is associated with 46XX, Swyer syndrome with 46XY, Turner syndrome with 45XO, and Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome with 46XY.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6th edition pg 446,447

choices.text: Temp > 100.4°F occurring 48h after delivery
Temp > 100.4°F occurring 24h after delivery
Temp > 100.4°F occurring 12h after delivery
Temp > 100.4°F occurring 6h after delivery

questions.text: Puerperal pyrexia is defined as: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Temp > 100.4°F occurring 24h after delivery

 

Puerperal pyrexia, also known as postpartum fever, is defined as a maternal temperature exceeding 100.4°F (38°C) after the first 24 hours postpartum. The initial 24-hour period following delivery is not considered because any fever during this time can be a reaction to the stress of labor and delivery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Puerperal pyrexia is defined as a temperature greater than 100.4°F occurring 24 hours after delivery, indicating postpartum infection or other complications.

questions.text: Where will be the level of the uterus 48 hours after delivery?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2.5 cm below umbilicus

 

  • Following delivery, the uterus is at the level of the umbilicus
  • it remains at level of umbilicus for 24 hours. Following this, it involutes
  • It involutes 1.25 cm/ day form the 2nd day onwards
  • So, after 48 hours (2 days) post-delivery, the uterus will be felt 2.5 cm breadth below the umbilicus
  • It becomes a pelvic organ (no longer abdominally palpable) by 10-14 days
  • It becomes the size of a non-pregnant uterus by 6 weeks
  • alternatively, it reduces by 1 finger breadth / day from 2nd day post partum, till it becomes pelvic organ by 10-14 days

 

Educational Objective:

 

The uterus will be 2.5 cm below umbilicus on the second-day post-delivery.

 

Ref: Page no 169, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition

questions.text:
A 16-year-old girl with primary amenorrhea has the following features. What is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2018)

 

  • Normal stature
  • Thelarche - absent
  • FSH, LH - high
  • Karyotype - 46 XX
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gonadal dysgenesis

 

Explanation:

 

The probable diagnosis in this case is pure gonadal dysgenesis. Primary amenorrhea with absent secondary sexual characteristics (thelarche) and high levels of FSH and LH indicate hypergonadotropic hypogonadism, which suggests an ovarian cause. The karyotype 46 XX confirms gonadal dysgenesis.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Testicular feminizing syndrome/Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome

 

  • This condition occurs in individuals with a 46 XY karyotype.
  • Individuals with this syndrome have absent uterus and ovaries and exhibit secondary sexual development, especially breast development, due to peripheral production of estrogens.

 

Option C. Kallmann Syndrome

 

  • This is a cause of hypogonadotropic hypogonadism leading to primary amenorrhea.
  • It is associated with anosmia and absent secondary sexual characteristics.
  • FSH and LH levels are low in this condition.

 

Option D. Turner Syndrome

 

  • Characterized by a 45 XO karyotype.
  • Individuals have streak ovaries leading to low estrogen levels and absent secondary sexual characteristics.
  • FSH and LH levels are high.
  • A very important feature is short stature, which is not seen in the patient described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primary amenorrhea with high FSH and LH levels and a 46 XX karyotype indicates gonadal dysgenesis.

 

Ref: Page no 454, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

questions.text: A pregnant woman presents with a genital lesion as shown below. What is the best treatment option for her? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cryotherapy

 

Explanation:

 

The image depicts a genital wart, which is caused by the human papillomavirus (HPV), specifically referred to as condyloma acuminata. In the context of pregnancy, the treatment options for genital warts must be chosen with caution to ensure the safety of both the mother and the fetus.

 

Treatment Considerations in Pregnancy:

 

  • Cryotherapy: This method involves freezing the wart with liquid nitrogen, which is a safe and effective treatment for genital warts during pregnancy. It is widely preferred due to its safety profile and effectiveness.
  • Trichloroacetic acid is another safe option during pregnancy for treating genital warts.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Surgical excision: Though safe, it is not the first-line treatment in most cases unless the warts are extensive.

 

Option B. Podophyllin: Not recommended during pregnancy due to safety concerns.

 

Option C. 5% imiquimod: Also avoided during pregnancy due to safety concerns.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The best treatment option for genital warts in a pregnant woman is cryotherapy, as it is safe and effective during pregnancy.

choices.text: Uterine artery embolization

questions.text: A 33-year-old female patient comes with complaints of menorrhagia for the past 3 months. The duration and regularity of her menstrual cycles are normal. Non- hormonal management has been tried without success. What is the most appropriate next step? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hormonal therapy

 

Explanation:

 

  • Hormonal therapy is the next best management modality for menorrhagia when non-hormonal management has failed. This includes combined oral contraceptive pills or even progesterone-only devices like the LND-IUS.
  • First-line management includes non-hormonal treatment like NSAIDs and Tranexamic acid.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Uterine artery embolization: Uterine artery embolization is a surgical option and is considered when other treatments fail.

 

Option B. Endometrial ablation: Endometrial ablation is also a surgical option and should be considered after hormonal therapy.

 

Option D. Hysterectomy: Hysterectomy is the last resort and is used when all other management options fail or are contraindicated.

 

Educational Objective

 

Hormonal therapy, including combined oral contraceptive pills or progesterone-only devices like the LND-IUS, is the next best management step for menorrhagia when non-hormonal management has been ineffective.

 

Ref: Page no 197, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

choices.text: On the action line
Before the action line
On the alert line
After the alert line

questions.text: In a Partogram, where do you start plotting the cervical dilatation? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) On the alert line

 

Explanation:

 

In the WHO modified partograph, labor progression is charted using alert and action lines. The cervical dilatation is plotted starting in the active phase of labor, typically at 4 cm dilation.

 

  • Alert Line: Represents a cervical dilation rate of 1 cm per hour. The first marking of cervical dilatation should be on this line.
  • Action Line: Plotted 4 hours to the right of the alert line. It indicates when intervention should be considered if labor is not progressing as expected.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. On the action line: Plotting starts on the alert line, not the action line. The action line is used for intervention planning.

 

Option B. Before the action line: This is incorrect as the plotting starts on the alert line.

 

Option D. After the alert line: This is incorrect since plotting should start on the alert line.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a Partogram, cervical dilatation is first plotted on the alert line, which indicates the expected rate of progress in labor.

 

Ref: https://iris.who.int/bitstream/handle/10665/337693/9789240017566-eng.pdf

choices.text: 200 mg

questions.text: The maximum dose of PGF2 alpha in postpartum hemorrhage is? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2 mg

 

Explanation:

 

Prostaglandin F2 alpha (PGF2α), also known as carboprost, is used for the treatment of postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) due to uterine atony. The therapeutic regimen and maximum dosage are crucial for effective management and patient safety.

 

  • Dose and Administration: The approved dose for treating uterine atony with PGF2α is 0.25 mg administered intramuscularly (IM).
  • Maximum Dose: The maximum cumulative dose is 2 mg. This is achieved by administering a total of 8 doses of 0.25 mg each.
  • Dosing Interval: These doses can be repeated at intervals of 15 to 90 minutes, depending on the clinical response and the patient's condition.

 

Contraindications

 

  • Bronchial Asthma: PGF2α can cause bronchoconstriction, which makes it contraindicated in patients with bronchial asthma.
  • Suspected Amniotic Fluid Embolism: Due to its potential to cause pulmonary airway and vascular constriction, it is also contraindicated in cases of suspected amniotic fluid embolism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 0.25 mg: This is the single dose administered IM but not the cumulative maximum dose.

 

Option C. 20 mg: This dose is excessively high and not clinically recommended or safe.

 

Option D. 200 mg: This dose is not applicable for human use and is far beyond the safe and recommended limits.

 

Educational Objective

 

The maximum dose of prostaglandin F2 alpha in the management of postpartum hemorrhage is 2 mg, administered in 0.25 mg increments intramuscularly.

 

Ref: Page no 480, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition

questions.text: When is suction and evacuation done? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 12 weeks

 

Explanation:

 

Suction and evacuation, also known as dilation and evacuation (D&E), is a common surgical method for medical termination of pregnancy. This procedure is typically performed up to 12 weeks of gestation (esp. for 9-12 weeks).

 

The process involves:

 

  1. Dilation of the cervix: This can be achieved mechanically using instruments like Hegar's dilators or medically with misoprostol.
  2. Evacuation of uterine contents: This is done using a suction machine, which can be either a manual vacuum aspirator (MVA) or an electric vacuum aspirator (EVA). In some cases, ovum forceps may also be used to assist in the evacuation.

 

Medical methods of termination are usually preferred between 5 to 9 weeks of gestation. After 9 weeks, surgical methods like suction and evacuation become more effective and are the preferred option.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 15 weeks: Beyond the recommended period for suction and evacuation; other methods may be considered.

 

Option C. 6 weeks: Medical methods are often preferred at this early stage, though suction and evacuation can be performed.

 

Option D. 18 weeks: Typically, more advanced surgical methods or induction of labor would be considered for termination at this stage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Suction and evacuation is best performed up to 12 weeks of gestation, making it the preferred surgical method for early medical termination of pregnancy.

questions.text: A pregnant woman presents for a routine antenatal checkup at 18 weeks of gestation. On abdominal examination, the uterine size was found to correspond to 16 weeks of gestation. On US, oligohydramnios was found. Which of the following is a likely cause? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Renal agenesis

 

  • Early onset oligohydramnios can be due to renal anomalies like
    • B/l renal agenesis
    • B/l dysplastic kidneys
    • B/l Autosomal recessive infantile polycystic kidney disease

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fetal anemia: Severe fetal anemia also can cause hydrops and polyhydramnios like in Twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome and Rh iso-immunization

 

Option C. Barter syndrome and option D. Anencephaly cause polyhydramnios

 

Educational Objective

 

Early onset oligohydramnios can be due to renal anomalies like bilateral renal agenesis, bilateral dysplastic kidneys, or bilateral autosomal recessive infantile polycystic kidney disease.

 

Ref: Page no 352, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: All the following are indications of caesarean section except? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Previous history of macrosomia

 

Explanation:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Options B, C and D are Absolute Indications for caesarean section. It means vaginal delivery is not possible

 

Absolute indications for caesarean section include:

 

  • Central placenta praevia
  • Contracted pelvis or CPD
  • Pelvic mass causing obstruction
  • Advanced CA cervix
  • Vaginal obstruction (atresia, stenosis)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Previous history of macrosomia is not an indication for caesarean section.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics page 670

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman in her second pregnancy is diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis (DVT) at 30 weeks gestation. What is the drug of choice for her treatment? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) LMWH (Low Molecular Weight Heparin)

 

Low Molecular Weight Heparin (LMWH). LMWH is the preferred treatment for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) during pregnancy due to its safety profile and ease of monitoring. LMWH does not cross the placenta, making it safer for the fetus compared to other anticoagulants. Additionally, LMWH requires less frequent monitoring compared to unfractionated heparin, making it more convenient for both patients and healthcare providers during pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Warfarin: Warfarin is contraindicated in pregnancy because it crosses the placenta and can lead to fetal complications, including congenital malformations and bleeding. Warfarin is generally reserved for patients with specific conditions such as mechanical heart valves who were already on the drug before pregnancy, under careful supervision.

 

Option C. Fondaparinux: While Fondaparinux is an anticoagulant, it is not the first-line choice for DVT in pregnancy. It is generally considered when LMWH is contraindicated, such as in cases of heparin-induced thrombocytopenia.

 

Option D. Apixaban: Apixaban, a direct oral anticoagulant (DOAC), is not recommended in pregnancy due to insufficient safety data. DOACs are generally avoided during pregnancy because they can cross the placenta and pose risks to the fetus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In pregnancy, the drug of choice for treating DVT is Low Molecular Weight Heparin (LMWH) due to its safety and ease of monitoring compared to other anticoagulants

choices.text: Placental site trophoblastic tumor
Invasive mole

questions.text: Gestational trophoblastic neoplasm does not include? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Partial mole

 

Explanation:

 

Gestational trophoblastic disease (GTD) includes a spectrum of conditions characterized by abnormal trophoblastic proliferation. These conditions are broadly classified into molar and non-molar trophoblastic diseases.

 

  • Hydatidiform Mole:
    • Complete Mole
    • Partial Mole
    • Invasive Mole
  • Non-Molar Trophoblastic Diseases:
    • Choriocarcinoma
    • Placental Site Trophoblastic Tumor
    • Epithelioid Trophoblastic Tumor

 

Gestational Trophoblastic Neoplasia (GTN), on the other hand, includes only the malignant forms of trophoblastic disease:

 

  1. Invasive Mole
  2. Choriocarcinoma
  3. Placental Site Trophoblastic Tumor
  4. Epithelioid Trophoblastic Tumor

 

A partial mole is a type of hydatidiform mole and is considered benign. It is not included under GTN as it does not have malignant potential unless it transforms into an invasive mole, which is rare.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Choriocarcinoma: This is a malignant form of GTD and is classified under GTN.

 

Option C. Placental Site Trophoblastic Tumor: This is another malignant form of GTD and is included under GTN.

 

Option D. Invasive Mole: An invasive mole is a malignant transformation of a hydatidiform mole and is included under GTN.

 

Educational Objective

 

Partial moles are not classified as gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN) because they are generally benign and non-malignant.

 

Ref: Page no 615, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Uterine artery - Ovarian artery - Internal iliac artery
Uterine artery - Ovarian artery- External iliac artery
Uterine artery - Ovarian artery - Vaginal artery
Uterine artery - pudendal artery - Vaginal artery

questions.text: A patient developed atonic postpartum hemorrhage after a normal vaginal delivery. She was shifted to the OT and the obstetrician planned ligation of vessels to arrest the bleeding. What is the order of ligation of the blood vessels supplying the uterus? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Uterine artery – Ovarian artery – Internal iliac artery

 

  • Stepwise devascularization in the management of atonic postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) involves:
    1. Ligation of the uterine arteries:
      • The ascending branch of the uterine artery is ligated at the lateral border between the upper and lower uterine segments.
    2. Ligation of the ovarian and uterine artery anastomoses:
      • Done just below the ovarian ligament.
      • Sometimes, temporary occlusion of the ovarian vessels may be achieved using rubber sleeved clamps.
    3. Ligation of the anterior division of the internal iliac artery:
      • This step reduces blood flow by decreasing the pulse pressure by 85%.
      • Ligation can be unilateral or bilateral.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Uterine artery - Ovarian artery - External iliac artery: The external iliac artery is not typically involved in the stepwise devascularization for managing atonic PPH.

 

Option C. Uterine artery - Ovarian artery - Vaginal artery: Ligation of the vaginal artery is not part of the typical sequence in managing atonic PPH.

 

Option D. Uterine artery - pudendal artery - Vaginal artery: The pudendal artery and vaginal artery are not typically targeted in the stepwise devascularization for atonic PPH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The stepwise devascularization approach for managing atonic postpartum hemorrhage includes ligation of the uterine arteries, ovarian arteries, and anterior division of the internal iliac arteries in that specific order.

 

Ref: Page no 2023, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl presented with amenorrhea. On examination, she had normal genitalia & normal breast development. Her tests reveal a 5 alpha-reductase deficiency. What could be the probable diagnosis?  (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Male pseudohermaphrodite

 

  • The clinical vignette is suggestive of male pseudohermaphroditism.
  • In pseudohermaphroditism, the sex glands are of one sex while the external genitalia are of the opposite sex.
  • Male pseudohermaphroditism (male intersex) is an association of male gonads with female external genitalia.
  • In 5 alpha-reductase deficiency, there is a failure of the testis to descend to the scrotum and ill development of the penis, thereby resulting in the female phenotype.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Concealed sex: Criminals may conceal their sex to avoid detection by changing dress or by other methods. This is not relevant to the clinical scenario presented.

 

Option B. True hermaphroditism: In this condition, the glands of both sexes must be present in the same individual. Such cases are very rare. In most cases, the accessory sex gland is atrophic and lacks functional activity.

 

Option C. Female pseudohermaphrodite: The fault is at the level of an enzyme block of 17-hydroxyprogesterone (21 hydroxylase deficiency is the most common cause) leading to defective production of sex steroids. There are features of virilization (clitoromegaly and the fused labioscrotal folds resemble a rudimentary scrotum). The ovaries may descend within the inguinal canal to lie in the labia majora simulating an inguinal testis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Male pseudohermaphroditism involves male gonads with female external genitalia. In 5 alpha-reductase deficiency, there is a failure of the testis to descend and ill development of the penis, resulting in a female phenotype despite having male internal genitalia.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of gynecology  6th edition pg 443

choices.text: ﻿﻿﻿Amniotic fluid index determination

questions.text: Identify the procedure done in the labor room? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cardiotocography

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows a procedure called Cardiotocography (CTG). CTG is a method used to monitor the fetal heart rate (FHR) and uterine contractions during pregnancy and labor. It helps assess the well-being of the fetus and identify any signs of fetal distress.

 

Key points about Cardiotocography (CTG):

 

  • If done antenatally (when the patient is not in labor), it is called a Non-Stress Test (NST).
  • During labor, CTG is used to continuously monitor the fetal heart rate and contractions to ensure the fetus is not in distress.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Amniocentesis: Amniocentesis is an invasive procedure in which a sample of amniotic fluid is aspirated for prenatal diagnosis or therapeutic purposes. This is not the procedure shown in the image.

 

Option B. MCA Doppler: MCA (Middle Cerebral Artery) Doppler is performed to assess fetal growth restriction and fetal anemia. It is an ultrasound procedure and does not match the image shown.

 

Option D. Amniotic Fluid Index (AFI): AFI is an ultrasound estimation of amniotic fluid volume. It is not depicted in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cardiotocography (CTG) is used to monitor the fetal heart rate and uterine contractions during pregnancy and labor. When performed antenatally without labor, it is referred to as a Non-Stress Test (NST).

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 24th edition pg339, Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition pg122

choices.text: ﻿﻿﻿Velamentous insertion of the cord
﻿﻿﻿Both succenturiate lobe and velamentous insertion

questions.text: The given image depicts: (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Both succenturiate lobe and velamentous insertion

 

Explanation:

 

  • Succenturiate lobe: This refers to a placenta with one or more accessory lobes connected to the main part of the placenta by blood vessels. It is characterized by the presence of a smaller, separate lobe in addition to the main placental mass.
  • Velamentous insertion of the cord: This occurs when the umbilical cord inserts into the fetal membranes (chorioamnion) rather than directly into the placental mass. The vessels then travel through the membranes to reach the placenta, making them vulnerable to rupture.
  • The image shows both conditions: a smaller accessory lobe (succenturiate lobe) and the cord inserting into the membranes rather than the placenta (velamentous insertion).

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Succenturiate lobe: This option is partially correct but does not account for the velamentous insertion.

 

Option B. Velamentous insertion of the cord: This option is partially correct but does not account for the succenturiate lobe.

 

Option D. Normal placenta: This is incorrect as the image shows abnormalities not seen in a normal placenta.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A placenta with both a succenturiate lobe and velamentous insertion of the cord is characterized by the presence of a smaller accessory lobe and the umbilical cord inserting into the fetal membranes.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 24th edition pg122, 117, Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition pg 251,253

choices.text: Transcervical resection of septum

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman visits the infertility clinic with a complaint of recurrent abortions. Upon investigations, she is found to have a septate uterus. Which of the following corrective procedures has the best obstetric outcome? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Transcervical resection of septum

 

Explanation:

 

  • Transcervical hysteroscopic resection of the septum has the best obstetric outcome.
  • The procedure involves the resection of the septum under hysteroscopic guidance. Hence, it doesn't scar the uterus and avoids the necessity of Cesarean sections for future pregnancies improving the obstetric outcomes.

 

 

Other Options

 

Metroplasty is a type of unification procedures in mullerian anomalies

 

Option A. Jones metroplasty and Option C. Tompkins metroplasty are for septate uterus but are not preferred now. As now the treatment of choice is hysteroscopic resection of the septa.

 

Option B. Strassman metroplasty: Strassman metroplasty is for bicornuate uterus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transcervical hysteroscopic resection of the septum is the best corrective procedure for a septate uterus to improve obstetric outcomes, as it does not scar the uterus and allows for future vaginal deliveries.

 

Ref: Page no 659, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

questions.text: A young girl presents with retention of urine and cyclical abdominal pain. On examination, there is a tense bluish bulge seen at the introitus. The diagnosis is? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Imperforate hymen

 

An imperforate hymen is a congenital disorder where the hymen, a thin membrane that typically surrounds or partially covers the vaginal opening, completely obstructs the vaginal opening. This condition can lead to the accumulation of menstrual blood within the vagina (hematocolpos) and uterus (hematometra), resulting in cyclical abdominal pain and urinary retention due to pressure on the bladder.

 

The classic presentation includes:

 

  • Cyclical abdominal pain: This occurs as menstrual blood accumulates but cannot exit the body, leading to distension and discomfort.
  • Retention of urine: The accumulated blood can exert pressure on the bladder and urethra, causing difficulty in urination.
  • Tense bluish bulge at the introitus: This is a distinctive finding in imperforate hymen, where the accumulated blood stretches the hymen, causing it to appear bluish and bulging at the vaginal opening.

 

The treatment for an imperforate hymen typically involves making a cruciate incision in the hymen to drain the accumulated blood (hematocolpos) and relieve the symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Transverse vaginal septum: This condition involves a fibrous or muscular wall across the vagina, which can also cause symptoms similar to an imperforate hymen, such as hematocolpos and urinary retention. However, it does not usually present with the characteristic tense bluish bulge at the introitus because the septum is thicker and the blood does not push against the hymen.

 

Option C. Vertical vaginal septum: A vertical vaginal septum is a partition that divides the vaginal canal into two parts. While it may lead to reproductive issues or dyspareunia, it typically does not cause urinary retention or cyclical pain as described in this case, nor does it present with a bluish bulge.

 

Option D. Mullerian agenesis: This is a congenital absence of the uterus, cervix, and upper part of the vagina. Patients with this condition often present with primary amenorrhea but do not typically have cyclical abdominal pain or urinary retention. Additionally, there would be no bluish bulge at the introitus because there is no accumulation of blood.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of cyclical abdominal pain, urinary retention, and a tense bluish bulge at the introitus in a young girl strongly suggests an imperforate hymen. Early diagnosis and surgical intervention can prevent complications and relieve symptoms.

choices.text: Low MSAFP, high hCG, low UE3
High MSAFP, low hCG, high UE3
Low MSAFP, high hCG, high UE3
High MSAFP, low hCG, low UE3

questions.text: A pregnant woman has a fetus with Down's syndrome. Triple test done at 15-16 weeks will have? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Low MSAFP, high hCG, low UE3

 

Explanation:

 

The triple and quadruple test is done between 15 – 21 weeks.

 

  • Components of Triple test are: Free β hCG, unconjugated Estriol (uE3) and Maternal Serum α-fetoprotein.
  • Components of the Quadruple test are: Free β hCG, unconjugated Estriol (uE3), Maternal Serum α-fetoprotein. And Inhibin A.

 

 

*Easy to remember: B for Big; so in Down’s syndrome; Beta hCG and InhiBin A: Big/ Increased

 

Educational Objective:

 

The triple test results for Down's syndrome typically show low MSAFP, high hCG, and low uE3.

 

Ref: Page 859, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman came to the OPD with a diagnosis of advanced cervical cancer. She has a 14-year-old daughter. What advice would you give for her daughter? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Advise HPV vaccine

 

The patient's 14-year-old daughter should be advised to take the HPV vaccine.

 

Screening CA cervix begins at the age of 25 years.

 

HPV vaccine

 

  • Contains recombinant VLP (L1 synthetic capsid protein)
  • Types –
    • Cervarix: Bivalent (16,18)
    • Gardasil: Quadrivalent (6,11,16,18)
    • Gardasil 9: Nonavalent (6, 11, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52, 58)
    • Dosing as per IAP:
      • Girls 9 to 14 years: 2 doses
      • > 15 years: 3 doses

 

On June 1, 2023 there will be the launch of Indian indigenous vaccine called Cervavac , quadrivalent vaccine produce by Serum Institute of India (6, 11, 16, 18).

 

WHO’s Safe Advisory Group (SAGE) in 2021 advised regarding updating dose schedules for HPV as follows:

 

  • One or two-dose schedule for the primary target of girls aged 9-14
  • One or two-dose schedule for young women aged 15-20
  • Two doses with a 6-month interval for women older than 21

 

Immunocompromised individuals, including those with HIV, should receive three doses if feasible, and if not at least two doses. There is limited evidence regarding the efficacy of a single dose in this group.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Screen for BRCA mutation: BRCA mutation causes breast cancer, ovarian cancer, endometrial cancer

 

Option C. Screen for PTEN mutation: PTEN mutation (chromosome 10) causes Cowden syndrome, has 20-30% risk of developing endometrial cancer.

 

Option D. Perform cervical biopsy: Cervical biopsy is not indicated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The HPV vaccine is essential for preventing cervical cancer and should be administered to girls aged 9 to 14 years, ideally before the onset of sexual activity.

questions.text: Which of the following graphs represents normal response to OGTT? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Graph D

 

Explanation:

 

The normal response to an Oral Glucose Tolerance Test (OGTT) is depicted by Graph D. During an OGTT, a patient ingests a specified amount of glucose (commonly 75 grams), and blood glucose levels are measured at intervals to evaluate how well the body handles glucose. In a normal response:

 

  • Blood glucose levels rise to a peak within 1 hour after ingestion.
  • Glucose levels then decline and return to baseline by 2 hours.
  • The glucose levels do not exceed the renal threshold at any point during the test.

 

This pattern reflects the body's effective regulation of blood glucose levels and the normal function of insulin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Graph A: Graph A might depict an abnormal glucose tolerance curve, such as one seen in impaired glucose tolerance or gestational diabetes, where glucose levels remain elevated for a prolonged period or fail to return to baseline.

 

Option B. Graph B: Graph B could show a response with an abnormal peak or delayed return to baseline, indicative of glucose intolerance or a diagnostic criterion for diabetes mellitus.

 

Option C. Graph C: Graph C might represent an exaggerated glucose peak or prolonged elevated glucose levels, suggesting a pathological glucose tolerance response consistent with diabetes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A normal OGTT response features a peak in blood glucose levels within 1 hour, followed by a return to baseline levels within 2 hours, without exceeding the renal threshold.

 

Ref: https://www.researchgate.net/publication/301045468_VARIANTS_OF_ORAL_GLUCOSE_TOLERANCE_TEST_OGTT_CURVE_IN_GESTATIONAL_DIABETES_MELLITUS_GDM

questions.text: Which of the following is not a long-acting reversible contraceptive method? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Laparoscopic tubal ligation


Laparoscopic tubal ligation is a permanent form of contraception and is not classified as a long-acting reversible contraceptive (LARC). It involves the surgical closure or blocking of the fallopian tubes to prevent pregnancy permanently.

 

Long-acting reversible contraceptive (LARC) methods are effective for extended periods and can be reversed if desired. They include:

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Copper T: Correct. Copper T is an intrauterine device (IUD) that can provide contraception for several years.

 

Option B. Implanon: Correct. Implanon is a type of contraceptive implant that provides effective contraception for several years.

 

Option D. SC DMPA: This is a LARC. It is a sub cutaneous preparation of depot medroxy progesterone acetate and is administered once in 3 months

 

Educational Objective:


Laparoscopic tubal ligation is a permanent method of contraception and is not a long-acting reversible contraceptive (LARC).

choices.text: Luteal phase LH
Post luteal phase LH
FSH in the follicular phase

questions.text: Which of the following is the best measures ovarian reserve? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Anti-Mullerian hormone (AMH)

 

Explanation:

 

  • Anti-Mullerian Hormone (AMH) is a glycoprotein secreted by the granulosa cells of pre-antral follicles. It is the best marker of ovarian reserve because it can be tested on any day of the cycle.
  • Values and Interpretation:
    • Normal value: 2-6.8 ng/mL
    • Poor ovarian reserve: <1 ng/mL
    • Polycystic Ovary Disease (PCOD) and Hyperstimulation Syndrome: >10 ng/mL

 

Tests for ovarian reserve:

 

  • FSH levels: Measured in the early follicular phase (Day 2 or 3 of the menstrual cycle). High FSH means the ovarian reserve is getting depleted.
  • Serum estradiol values: Measured on day 3 of the cycle. Serum estradiol >75 pg/mL indicates ovarian hypofunction.
  • Antral follicular count on ultrasound: Counts less than 4-5 on days 2-5 denote poor response to hormones.
  • Inhibin B: Values <40 pg/mL indicate poor reserve.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Luteal phase LH: Not a reliable measure of ovarian reserve.

 

Option B. Post luteal phase LH: Not a reliable measure of ovarian reserve.

 

Option C. FSH in the follicular phase: While useful, it is less reliable than AMH for assessing ovarian reserve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anti-Mullerian Hormone (AMH) is the best marker of ovarian reserve as it can be tested on any day of the menstrual cycle and provides a reliable measure of the ovarian reserve.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6th edition Pg 528,529, William’s textbook of gynecology 3rd edition pg435

choices.text: Endodermal sinus tumor
Malignant teratoma
Mucinous cystadenocarcinoma

questions.text: A 16-year-old female patient presents with an ovarian mass. On further evaluation, her serum biomarkers are found to be normal except for LDH, which is found to be elevated. The most likely diagnosis is: (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dysgerminoma

 

Explanation:

 

The given clinical history of a 16-year-old female presenting with an ovarian mass with raised LDH points towards the diagnosis of dysgerminoma. Dysgerminomas usually arise in young women or in children, with an average incidence at the age of 20. They currently account for approximately one-third of all malignant ovarian germ cell tumors and are the most common malignant ovarian tumors found in pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Endodermal sinus tumor: This is typically associated with elevated alpha-fetoprotein (AFP), not LDH.

 

Option C. Malignant teratoma: This type of tumor does not typically present with elevated LDH as the sole abnormal marker.

 

Option D. Mucinous cystadenocarcinoma: This epithelial ovarian tumor is usually associated with elevated CA-125, not LDH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dysgerminoma is the most likely diagnosis in a young female with an ovarian mass and elevated LDH levels.

 

Ref: Page no 381, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

choices.text: 5 alpha reductase deficiency
17 alpha hydroxylase deficiency
Androgen insensitivity syndrome

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl comes in with primary amenorrhea and indications of virilization. She displays underdeveloped breasts and pubic hair consistent with prepubertal stages, rated at Tanner stage 2. She has a closed-off vaginal canal and noticeable enlargement of the clitoris. Despite her female sex, her testosterone levels are within the male range. Her genetic makeup is 46XY. What is the likely medical diagnosis in this case? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 5 alpha reductase deficiency

 

Explanation:

 

The given scenario points to a diagnosis of 5 alpha reductase deficiency.

 

5 alpha reductase deficiency causes inability to convert testosterone to DHT.

 

When DHT levels are low, newborns will possess external genitalia with a feminine appearance. These youngsters are commonly brought up as girls until they reach puberty, at which point they begin to display signs of masculinization due to the influence of testosterone. As a result, clitoromegaly becomes evident. The absence of estrogen conversion from testosterone results in limited breast growth. Scanty pubic hair is observed since its growth is contingent on both testosterone and dihydrotestosterone.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 17 alpha hydroxylase deficiency: Leads to reduced formation of corticosteroids, sex hormones and increased mineralocorticoids (causing hypokalemia and hypertension). Patient with XY chromosome presents with atypical genitalia and undescended testes. Patient with XX chromosome lacks secondary sexual development.

 

Option C. Androgen insensitivity syndrome: Defect in androgen receptor resulting in female-appearing genetic male (46, XY); female external genitalia with scant axillary and pubic hair, rudimentary vagina; uterus and fallopian tubes absent due to persistence of anti-Mullerian hormone from testes. Patients develop normal functioning testes. Patient has increased testosterone, estrogen & LH as compared to other sex chromosome disorders.

 

Option D. Swyer syndrome: 46 XY gonadal dysgenesis; Absent secondary sexual characters, but normal female internal and external genitalia. Gonadectomy needs to be done.

 

Educational Objective:

 

5-alpha reductase deficiency causes primary amenorrhea and virilization in genetic females (46XY), resulting in the inability to convert testosterone to dihydrotestosterone (DHT). This leads to female external genitalia at birth and masculinization at puberty, with signs such as clitoromegaly and underdeveloped breasts.

choices.text: Fetal head 5/5 palpable on abdominal examination
Two contractions lasting for 10 seconds in 10 minutes
More than 5 cm cervical dilatation with complete effacement

questions.text: A primigravida presents to the labor room at 40 weeks of gestation with lower abdominal pain. She has been in labor for 3 hours. Which of the following will determine if she is in active labor?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) More than 5 cm cervical dilatation with complete effacement

 

  • More than 5 cm cervical dilatation with complete effacement:
    • According to the World Health Organization (WHO) Labor Care Guide (LCG), active labor begins at more than 5 cm of cervical dilatation.
    • The older definition of active labor was at 4 cm of cervical dilatation.
    • The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG) now defines active labor as beginning at more than 6 cm of cervical dilatation.
    • Complete effacement indicates that the cervix has thinned out, which is a key indicator of active labor progression.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fetal head 5/5 palpable on abdominal examination: This indicates that the fetal head is still high in the pelvis and not yet engaged. It does not determine active labor.

 

Option B. Two contractions lasting for 10 seconds in 10 minutes: This frequency and duration of contractions are not sufficient to determine active labor. Active labor typically involves regular, strong contractions lasting 45-60 seconds and occurring every 2-3 minutes.

 

Option D. Rupture of membranes: While rupture of membranes can occur during labor, it is not a definitive indicator of active labor. Cervical dilation and effacement are more reliable indicators.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Active labor is determined by more than 5 cm of cervical dilatation with complete effacement, according to the WHO Labor Care Guide.

 

Ref: Page no 138, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition

questions.text: A G2P1L1 with a previous cesarean section now presents at term. Which of the following is most favorable for a vaginal birth? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Previous lower segment cesarean

 

Explanation:

 

The type of uterine incision from a previous cesarean section significantly impacts the safety and likelihood of a successful vaginal birth after caesarean (VBAC).

 

The lower segment cesarean section (LSCS) involves a transverse incision made in the lower, thinner part of the uterus. This type of incision is most favorable for a vaginal birth due to its lower risk of uterine rupture during labor, which is around 0.2%.

 

Other Options:

 

Other Incision Types and Associated Risks:

 

Option A. Previous upper segment cesarean: This is also known as a classical cesarean section, where the incision is made vertically in the thicker, upper part of the uterus. The risk of uterine rupture with this type of incision is significantly higher, ranging from 4-9%.

 

Option C. Previous J-shaped cesarean: This incision extends from the lower segment into the upper segment, increasing the risk of rupture to 4-9%.

 

Option D. Previous T-shaped cesarean: This incision combines a lower segment transverse incision with a vertical extension into the upper segment, also associated with a 4-9% risk of rupture.

 

Educational objective:

 

The most favorable incision for a vaginal birth after a previous cesarean section is the lower segment transverse incision due to its lower risk of uterine rupture during labor.

choices.text: Iron prophylaxis is given for 6 months antepartum and 6 months postpartum
Iron prophylaxis is started at 14 weeks and continued for 6 weeks after delivery
Iron prophylaxis starts in the 1st trimester and continues till 6 weeks postpartum
Iron prophylaxis is given 6 months antepartum and 3 months postpartum

questions.text: As per Anemia Mukt Bharat, which is the correct statement regarding iron prophylaxis in pregnant women? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Iron prophylaxis is given for 6 months antepartum and 6 months postpartum

 

Explanation:

 

The Anemia Mukt Bharat (AMB) initiative outlines that iron prophylaxis for pregnant women should start from the 14th week of pregnancy and continue throughout the pregnancy (approximately 6 months) and for 6 months postpartum. The recommended dosage is one red-colored, sugar-coated tablet containing 60 mg of elemental iron and 0.5 mg of folic acid daily. This regimen helps in preventing iron deficiency anemia and folate deficiency anemia during and after pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Iron prophylaxis for pregnant women under the Anemia Mukt Bharat initiative is given from 14 weeks of pregnancy and continues for 6 months postpartum.

questions.text: Asherman syndrome is most commonly associated with? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hypomenorrhea

 

  • Asherman syndrome is the presence of uterine synechiae, due to the destruction of the endometrium. It can occur because of
    • Trauma to the endometrium following vigorous curettages such as incomplete abortion, postpartum hemorrhage, and elective abortion.
    • Genital tuberculosis
  • C/F: Following a D & C, they present with
    • Hypomenorrhea
    • Secondary amenorrhoea
    • Secondary infertility
  • The diagnosis is made by
    • HSG: Moth eaten appearance/ intra cavitary filling defects
    • Hysteroscopy: Intra uterine adhesions are seen

 

 

  • Management: Hysteroscopic adhesiolysis f/b insertion of an IUCD for 3 months and giving estrogen to build the endometrium

 

 Other Options:

 

Option A. Oligomenorrhea: This refers to infrequent menstruation, which is not the primary symptom of Asherman syndrome. Although it can occur, hypomenorrhea is more characteristic of the condition.

 

Option C. Dysmenorrhea: This means painful menstruation, which is not typically associated with Asherman syndrome.

 

Option D. Menorrhagia: This refers to heavy menstrual bleeding. Asherman syndrome usually leads to hypomenorrhea rather than menorrhagia due to the reduced endometrial surface area.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Asherman syndrome is most commonly associated with hypomenorrhea due to intrauterine adhesions following endometrial trauma.

 

Ref: Page no 459, DC Dutta’s Textbook of gynecology 6th edition

choices.text: Supine with wedge under right hip
Trendelenburg with legs stirrup

questions.text: A woman presents with prolonged labor in emergency. She is being taken for a Cesarean section. Which of the following is the correct position in which the nurse should keep the patient on the OT table? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Supine with wedge under right hip

 

Explanation:

 

The preferred position for a cesarean section is supine with a wedge under the right hip. This positioning is crucial to prevent supine hypotension syndrome, which is commonly seen in the third trimester of pregnancy.

 

Supine hypotension syndrome:

 

  • Occurs due to the pressure of the gravid uterus on the inferior vena cava (IVC) when the patient is in the supine position.
  • This pressure can cause hypotension, tachycardia, and syncope.
  • It is particularly dangerous during cesarean sections where spinal anesthesia can exacerbate hypotension.
  • A right tilt (placing a wedge under the right hip) helps to alleviate the pressure on the IVC, thereby preventing hypotension.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Semi fowlers: The individual lies on the bed with the head elevated 30-45 degrees. This position is not suitable for a cesarean section.

 

Option C. Trendelenburg with legs stirrup: This position involves having the head low and is not appropriate for a cesarean section. The reverse Trendelenburg position (head high) is also not suitable for this purpose.

 

Option D. Prone position: The prone position (lying face down) is inappropriate for cesarean sections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During a cesarean section, the patient should be positioned supine with a wedge under the right hip to prevent supine hypotension syndrome, which is caused by the pressure of the gravid uterus on the inferior vena cava.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 26th edition pg 1405

questions.text: Which hormone is secreted by placenta? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) hCG

 

Explanation:

 

  • Human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) is the hormone secreted by the placenta. It is a glycoprotein produced by the syncytiotrophoblast cells of the placenta.
  • hCG can be detected in the maternal serum or urine as early as 8-9 days post-fertilization using radioimmunoassay. In early pregnancy, hCG concentrations in plasma double every 1.4-2 days.
  • The primary role of hCG is to maintain the corpus luteum during the beginning of pregnancy, ensuring the continued production of progesterone, which is critical for maintaining the uterine lining and supporting pregnancy.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. LH: Luteinizing Hormone is produced by the anterior pituitary gland, not by the placenta. It plays a key role in regulating the menstrual cycle and ovulation.

 

Option C. FSH: Follicle-Stimulating Hormone is also produced by the anterior pituitary gland. It is involved in the development of ovarian follicles and the regulation of the menstrual cycle.

 

Option D. GnRH: Gonadotropin-Releasing Hormone is produced by the hypothalamus, it stimulates the anterior pituitary gland to release FSH and LH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) is a hormone secreted by the placenta, crucial for maintaining early pregnancy by supporting the corpus luteum and progesterone production.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 26th edition pg266, Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition pg 66

questions.text: A patient presents at 18 weeks with low risk of trisomy on quadruple marker and high risk of NTD. What is the next best step? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anomaly scan

 

The correct answer is Anomaly scan. This patient has a low risk of trisomy (such as Down syndrome) but a high risk of neural tube defects (NTD) based on the quadruple marker test. The quadruple marker test includes measurements of beta-hCG, unconjugated estriol, inhibin A, and alpha-fetoprotein (AFP). A high level of AFP is associated with an increased risk of NTDs, such as spina bifida.

 

Given the elevated risk for NTDs, the most appropriate next step is an anomaly scan, specifically a targeted imaging for fetal anomaly (TIFA) scan. This ultrasound, typically performed between 18 and 20 weeks of gestation, has a high sensitivity (up to 99%) for detecting structural anomalies, particularly neural tube defects. The scan is a non-invasive way to assess the fetus for physical defects.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Amniocentesis: While amniocentesis can detect chromosomal abnormalities and some structural defects, it is invasive and carries a small risk of complications. Since the concern here is structural (NTD) rather than chromosomal, and the anomaly scan is highly effective and non-invasive, amniocentesis is not the first choice.

 

Option C. Chorionic villous sampling (CVS): CVS is another invasive procedure used for early genetic testing, usually performed in the first trimester. It is not useful at 18 weeks and is not the best test for detecting structural anomalies like NTDs.

 

Option D. NIPT (Non-Invasive Prenatal Testing): NIPT is a screening tool for chromosomal aneuploidies (like trisomy 21, 18, and 13). Since the patient already has a low risk of trisomy, NIPT is unnecessary and does not address the high risk of NTD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a patient with a high risk of neural tube defects identified by elevated alpha-fetoprotein on a quadruple marker test, the best next step is an anomaly scan (TIFA), which is highly effective in identifying structural fetal abnormalities, including NTDs

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl is seen for primary amenorrhea. She has not development of breasts or hair in the pubic or axillary region. Her height is 155cm and her weight is 48 kg. She has bilateral inguinal masses. On USG examination, the uterus, fallopian tube, and ovary are absent. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hypergonadotropic hypogonadism

 

Explanation:

 

  • The diagnosis based on the given clinical scenario is hypergonadotropic hypogonadism.
  • In this question, bilateral inguinal masses (undescended testis), absent ovary, also there is absent uterus and fallopian tubes, all pointing to a conclusion that patient can be of XY karyotype. Because if female reproductive tract is absent, there must be mullerian inhibiting substance present which comes from Y chromosome.
  • Hypergonadotropic hypogonadism can occur in disorders such as FSH or LH receptor mutations.
  • Now, in a XY individual with a defect in LH/hCG receptor, testis’ Sertoli cells will produce Anti-mullerian hormone which will not let uterus, fallopian tube, cervix, upper vagina to develop. Leydi cells will not produce testosterone due to which wolffian duct development is impaired and the testes fail to descend. They appear female at birth and at puberty present with primary amenorrhea. They lack breast development and pubic hair development.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Complete androgen insensitivity syndrome: Androgen insensitivity syndrome individuals have normal breast development.

 

Option C. Turner syndrome: Turner's syndrome karyotype is XO.

 

Option D. Polycystic ovary syndrome: In Polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS) ovary and uterus is present, so can’t be answer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypergonadotropic hypogonadism can present as primary amenorrhea with absent uterus, fallopian tubes, and ovaries in an XY individual, with bilateral inguinal masses indicating undescended testes.

choices.text: ﻿﻿﻿Gestational hypertension

questions.text: A baby was born at 34 weeks of pregnancy; the appearance of the baby is given below. What is the mother suffering from? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gestational diabetes

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows a large for gestational age (LGA) fetus. Macrosomia is a condition where a newborn baby is significantly larger than average. This can often be identified by a higher birth weight and size compared to typical babies born at the same gestational age.

 

Causes of Macrosomia:

 

  1. Gestational Diabetes Mellitus (GDM) and Overt Diabetes Mellitus:
    • Maternal hyperglycemia leads to fetal hyperglycemia, which stimulates insulin production in the fetus. Insulin acts as a growth hormone, leading to increased fetal growth and fat deposition.
  2. Maternal Obesity:
    • Increased maternal body mass index (BMI) is associated with a higher risk of delivering a macrosomic baby.
  3. Previous Baby with Macrosomia:
    • A history of delivering a large baby increases the risk of subsequent babies also being large.
  4. Post-term Pregnancy:
    • Pregnancy extending beyond the due date increases the chance of the baby growing larger.
  5. Excessive Weight Gain in Pregnancy:
    • Significant maternal weight gain during pregnancy contributes to larger fetal size.

 

Conditions Not Associated with Macrosomia:

 

  • Anemia and Antepartum Hemorrhage (APH): These conditions are typically associated with fetal growth restriction rather than macrosomia.
  • Thrombocytopenia: This condition has no direct association with fetal weight.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Rubella: Rubella infection during pregnancy can cause congenital rubella syndrome, which is typically associated with intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR), not macrosomia.

 

Option C. Hypothyroidism: Maternal hypothyroidism can lead to complications such as preterm birth and low birth weight but is not directly linked to macrosomia.

 

Option D. Gestational Hypertension: Gestational hypertension is associated with IUGR and preterm birth rather than increased fetal size.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gestational diabetes is a significant risk factor for macrosomia, leading to the birth of large for gestational age (LGA) babies.

 

Ref: Page no 2169, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: Identify the blue-colored area shown in the image below?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mid-pelvis

 

The true pelvis is divided into 3 planes

 

  1. Plane of Inlet
  2. Plane of Mid cavity (Mid-Pelvis)
  3. Plane of Outlet

 

The Plane of Mid Cavity (Or Mid-Pelvis) is what is shown in the image

 

Pelvic Cavity

 

This has 2 planes

 

  1. Plane of Greatest Dimension: 
    • At the level of S2/3
    • Circular plane; AP diameter = Transverse diameter = 12.5 cm
    • Widest part of pelvis
  2. Plane of Least dimension
    • At the level of S3/4
    • At the level of ischial spine
    • Very important plane CLINICALLY
      1. Narrowest part of pelvis
      2. Internal rotation takes place here
      3. Origin of levator ani
      4. Landmark for pudendal block
      5. When engagement occurs, the head is felt at 0 station, i.e., at this plane
      6. Deep Transverse Arrest occurs here

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Obstetric outlet:

 

  • Refers to the lower part of the pelvic outlet, which is wider than the anatomical outlet.
  • Not shown in the image.

 

Option B. Anatomical outlet:

 

  • Refers to the narrowest part of the pelvic outlet.
  • Not shown in the image.

 

Option C. Pelvic inlet:

 

  • Marks the entrance to the true pelvis.
  • Not shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The plane of the mid-pelvis (or mid cavity) is a crucial area within the true pelvis, significant for various clinical considerations during labor and delivery.

 

Ref: Page no 92 Textbook of obstetrics by JB Sharma

questions.text: The classification shown is for? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  B) Pelvic organ prolapse


The classification shown in the image is the Pelvic Organ Prolapse Quantification (POP-Q) system, which is used to classify pelvic organ prolapse.

 

Pelvic organ prolapse refers to the descent of pelvic organs, including the uterus, bladder, and rectum, into or outside of the vaginal canal. The POP-Q system is a standardized method that provides detailed measurements of the degree and location of prolapse using specific points and measurements.

 

The reference point in this classification is the hymen, and the system documents anterior wall descent, posterior wall descent, and other prolapse details through a 3x3 grid with six specific points (Aa, Ba, C, Ap, Bp, and D) and three measurements (genital hiatus, perineal body, and total vaginal length). This detailed system allows for accurate assessment and comparison of prolapse severity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cervical cancer:  is incorrect because cervical cancer staging does not use the POP-Q system. Instead, cervical cancer staging is typically done using FIGO (International Federation of Gynecology and Obstetrics) criteria, which focus on tumor size and spread rather than anatomical descent.

 

Option C. Vulvar cancer: is incorrect. Vulvar cancer staging is also not related to pelvic organ prolapse or the POP-Q classification. It typically involves examining tumor size and invasion depth.

 

Option D. Uterine anomalies: is incorrect because uterine anomalies refer to congenital abnormalities of uterine structure and do not involve prolapse quantification. These are usually diagnosed with imaging techniques like ultrasound or MRI, not classified with a system like POP-Q.

 

Educational Objective:


The POP-Q system is a specific and standardized classification method used to quantify and describe the extent of pelvic organ prolapse using detailed anatomical measurements. The hymen is the reference point for this classification.

questions.text: What is the best parameter for estimating fetal age during the first trimester using ultrasound? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Crown rump length

 

Explanation:

 

Crown rump length is the best parameter for estimating fetal age during the first trimester using ultrasound.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. Biparietal diameter, B. Head circumference and D. Abdominal circumference are parameters useful in second trimester

 

Educational Objective:

 

Crown rump length is the best parameter for estimating fetal age during the first trimester using ultrasound.

 

Ref: Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th Edition page 84

choices.text: Below pubic symphysis
Above pubic symphysis
Below umbilicus
Above umbilicus

questions.text: What is the true statement regarding level of uterus just after delivery? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Below umbilicus

 

Explanation:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Below pubic symphysis: This is not accurate immediately after delivery as the uterus is still quite large and palpable above the pubic symphysis.

 

Option B. Above pubic symphysis: While this is true in a general sense postpartum, it is not specific enough to accurately describe the position immediately after delivery.

 

Option D. Above umbilicus: This is incorrect because the uterus immediately after delivery is positioned at the lower border of the umbilicus, not above it.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Immediately after delivery, the uterus is positioned at the lower border of the umbilicus, equivalent to the size it would be at 20 weeks of gestation.

 

Ref: D. C. Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th Edition page 170

questions.text: A pregnant woman has gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) and her blood glucose levels are well controlled on insulin. What will be the appropriate gestational age for her delivery? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 39 weeks

 

Explanation:

 

The appropriate timing of delivery in a pregnant woman with gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) whose blood glucose levels are well controlled on insulin is at or after 39 weeks of gestation. This recommendation is based on the following considerations:

 

  • Lung Maturity: GDM pregnancies are associated with a delay in fetal lung maturity. Routine delivery before 39 weeks is generally not recommended to avoid respiratory complications in the newborn.
  • Induction of Labor: If the patient with well-controlled GDM has not delivered spontaneously by 39 weeks, induction of labor should be scheduled at or after 39 weeks to minimize the risks associated with GDM and to ensure fetal maturity.

 

Other important points in GDM:

 

  • Avoid Past Dates: Delivery should not be delayed beyond the expected due date to prevent complications.
  • Anticipate Shoulder Dystocia: There is an increased risk of shoulder dystocia in infants of mothers with GDM.
  • Prophylactic Cesarean Section (LSCS): Considered if the estimated fetal weight is greater than 4.5 kg to avoid complications during vaginal delivery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a pregnant woman with well-controlled gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) on insulin, the appropriate gestational age for delivery is at or after 39 weeks to ensure fetal lung maturity and reduce the risk of complications.

 

Ref: https://nhm.gov.in/images/pdf/programmes/maternal-health/guidelines/National_Guidelines_for_Diagnosis_&_Management_of_Gestational_Diabetes_Mellitus.pdf

questions.text: What hormones are secreted by the Leydig cells and the Sertoli cells respectively? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Testosterone and AMH

 

In the testes, Leydig cells and Sertoli cells have distinct roles and secrete different hormones crucial for male reproductive development and function:

 

  • Leydig cells: These cells are responsible for the production of testosterone. Testosterone plays a pivotal role in the development of male secondary sexual characteristics and is crucial for the growth of the ipsilateral Wolffian duct, which develops into the male internal genitalia. Additionally, testosterone is converted to dihydrotestosterone (DHT), which is essential for the development of male external genitalia.
  • Sertoli cells: These cells produce Anti-Mullerian Hormone (AMH), also known as Mullerian Inhibiting Substance (MIS). During male embryonic development, AMH is vital for inhibiting the growth of the Mullerian ducts, which would otherwise develop into female internal genitalia. The suppression of Mullerian duct development by AMH ensures the proper formation of male internal reproductive structures.

 

Note - Inhibin is secreted by Sertoli cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Leydig cells secrete testosterone
  • Sertoli cells secrete Anti-Mullerian Hormone (AMH) and Inhibin
